My financial advisor told me months ago to expect a market correction on housing. But it will most likely hit the upper income housing (500,000 plus) Everything else should hold it's own without a lot of loss or gain for a couple of years. Not to worry unless your setting in a million dollar home that's actually only worth half of that. Reality sets in.
 
 Relax, it's all good. Lock in your rate and ride it out.

Myself and a few otehr guys just recently hired a group fo top folks to do a report on this.
 
 Expect 1996 prices sometime in 2007. 
 
 The housing market is not that unpredictable. It is WAY, WAY out of wack in most parts of the country. 
 
 What we were looking for from the report, and didn't really get, was a reasonable expectation for over correction. Their best guess was likely 20%, but that was entirely guesswork based primarily on the japense market crash, .com bubble crash, etc....

My financial advisor told me months ago to expect a market correction on housing. But it will most likely hit the upper income housing (500,000 plus) Everything else should hold it's own without a lot of loss or gain for a couple of years. Not to worry unless your setting in a million dollar home that's actually only worth half of that. Reality sets in.
 
 Relax, it's all good. Lock in your rate and ride it out.

 
 We're seeing the opposite here based on 2004 4th qtr numbers. As predicted interest rate increases have reflected a 25% slowdown in units sold from $200-500k ($200k being a double wide on a small lot) due to lack of loan qualifying ability while $500-800k are down 10% and everything above that is still gaining and normally not reliant on financing. My area has no strong industrial base with both family members generally working to provide loan qualifying ratios in the under $500k market. 
 
 Real estate hiring has dropped 50% here while real estate schools are experiencing corresponding 50% enrollment decreases.

Not yet but it should get worse slowly,
 
 A housing correction generally takes more time then a stock market correction. When the number of forced sales either due to foreclosure or relocations increases expect the prices to stay at the very best stagnant ( Bad for California, and the East Coast with the high number of exotic mortgages in those areas). At the worst a 10-30% decline in many markets

As predicted interest rate increases have reflected a 25% slowdown in units sold from $200-500k ($200k being a double wide on a small lot) due to lack of loan qualifying ability while $500-800k are down 10% and everything above that is still gaining and normally not reliant on financing.  It seems to me that the situation in your area is a little unique in that it seems to be a trendy area for wealthy retirees to land. This is going to change the balance of the situation.
 
 IMO, Truthsayers financial advisor is full of it....likely trying to cover their butt because, like so many others, they have told people BUY, BUY, BUY. High end housing is self limiting. There are only so many folks who cn afford $ million + houses, and most of them are not given to foolish financial decisions. A bubble based on investors irrational exuberance is going to primarily effect the sector of the market that is reachable by the highest number of investors. In most cases, that would be the $50-$450k market segment. As you move into the upper end of the scale, fewer buyers are able to afford to enter the market. 
 
 In this case, with the creative financing available, that upper number probably moves to the $700-$800k range. 
 
 The most dramatic changes in the housing market have not been in the upper end of the spectrum, they have been in the middle and lower segments.

IMO, Truthsayers financial advisor is full of it...

 
 I thought the same a couple of years ago as my Washington Fund was taking a dive. But considering the fact that he makes about as much money in a day as you and I do in a month, I think it's safe to say that he is a bit more in tune than you or I.;) But you're free to think what you wish.emoticon_xgood 
 
 Meanwhile, Matt and I (my financial advisor) are steady racking in the bucks. The performance on my ING investments are climbing through the roof. I just pulled some of them and put them in a safe place anticipating a slow down. I don't want to see them disappear like they did a couple of years ago in the Washington Fund.

Not yet but it should get worse slowly,
 
 A housing correction generally takes more time then a stock market correction. When the number of forced sales either due to foreclosure or relocations increases expect the prices to stay at the very best stagnant ( Bad for California, and the East Coast with the high number of exotic mortgages in those areas). At the worst a 10-30% decline in many markets

 
 I have some 1st trust deeds subordinated to construction loans and spend time evaluating financial condition of the respective developers. Most (developers) are still flush from the boom with reserves of six months to service interest on 1st trust deeds and construction loans and their construction loans are 6-9 months of prepaid interest for build time. If a completed project doesn't sell in three months, a developer lowers the selling price (from top profit margin) and again at appropriate intervals. Foreclosures generally begin at 6-8 months after project completion, so I'm looking at late spring for that side of the housing market to falter.
 
 Resident or investor dwelling foreclosures will take longer as a decrease in new construction takes time for economic flow-through to impact mortgage holders due to unemployment benefits. And mortgage companies will 'work' with individual mortgage holders to avoid moving paper from performing to non-performing asset status. I think credit card delinquency will surface before foreclosures become prominent.

 IF you are spart, you will find some sweetheart foreign invetments. There are some excellent buys on the canadian market right now. Not only do you get the income from the stocks, including dividends, you generally catch an additional windfall on the exchange rate as the investmentds are non dollar.

Equity markets could become interesting when the fact that the housing boom is dwindling filters down to the general populace. I'd think a lot of folks are going to be in shock when they read the fine print on 401 withdrawals and subsequent tax penalties. I'd also think gamehuis and others are plotting some serious positions related to the building industry.

 Since our equity markets are primarly based on consumer confidence, not necessarily underlying value, "interesting" is putting it lightly. 
 
 Gold or silver is looking more attractive, since it is protected against both inflation and adjustments to consumer confidence. 
 
 As for me, I will probably keep playing currency, and to some extent, equity markets. I like to actively manage...sometimes micromanage.
 
 Despite my big retirement plans, I found retirement mind numbingly boring after just a few weeks. I would hide in my office checking the market like some kind of junky getting his fix. My saving grace was when my wife started her company and needed help, thus releasing me from my promise to do nothing for a year.

I have no idea how much you make in a month, but given some of your economic statements here I can easily believe he makes more in a day than you do in a month. 
 
 
 
 
 
 Likewise. Happy New Year.

Despite my big retirement plans, I found retirement mind numbingly boring after just a few weeks. I would hide in my office checking the market like some kind of junky getting his fix. My saving grace was when my wife started her company and needed help, thus releasing me from my promise to do nothing for a year.

 What about that Chebby pickup? I could (and do) spend lots of time on such projects. I LOVE retirement and find myself busy every day .... in a totally unscheduled way. The hardest part of adjusting to retirement for me was slowing down and learning that I no longer had to answer the bell. You are obviously a man of many interests with the means to pursue any of them. You have paid your dues and should seek that which brings you satisfaction at day's end. Good luck.
 Dono

 I am still working on the old chevy, and a few other projects.
 
 The problem seems to be that I have gotten used to running 18-20 hours per day. I just don't know what to do with the free time. I am sure I will figure somethign out...after I get my wifes business in line, and get out from under my current consulting contracts, and run out a couple other ideas I have rattling around in my head.
 
 The biggest bonus I have seen so far to retirement (if you can call thi retirement) is the ability to be irresponsible without feeling bad about it. For example, I was talking to a friend Sunday night that was taking his family to Branson for a couple days. He asked if we wanted to go along. I tossed the wife and the kids in the mini van monday morning and headed down. Just got back. A year ago, I would not have even considered it. Now I am retired so I figure "why the hell not??"
